bibl.title: Letter from A.S. Hardy to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 23, 1927

div1.p: Hardy expresses continued interest in lobbying Congress for the pension campaign.

div1.head: Letter from A.S. Hardy to Emilie Lawrence Reed, September 23, 1927
div1.opener:
431-Locust St
Johnson City-Tenn-
Sept 23d 1927
Mrs Walter Reed
Blue Ridge Summit Pa
Dear Madam
div1.p:
No doubt you think me
very blameworthy and perhaps I am as
I wrote you, Id send back the documents
you sent me, but Judge Cox's legal affairs
have given him much to do lately as he is
Chief Attorney for The Rayon silk Mill being
built near this town, capitalized at 37 million
dollars and having troubles over right of way & C
requiring his active attention and still at it

As I first applied to Judge Cox for aid in
this most worthy cause Ivewaited on him
as he is the most suitable man in this
section to do so We have had many copies
of the lecture struck off and shown to
or mailed to our friends in other sections
and States requesting their Cooperation
in this good work, and we hope for
good results from their trying to
bring their Congressmen to aid in bringing
this matter to a proper appreciation of
over
not only Congress-but the general public

I sincerely trust this good cause may
soon come to a just and happy ending

Your righteous course has two things
in the way that are almost invincible
to remove 1st Dr Reed came from South
of Mason & Dixon line 2nd People in
general are somewhat crazed over the
popular things occupying their attention
such as- Flying - Prize fighting & c making
it difficult to bring them to see that this
is a real test of justice and National honor

I am sure the people are your friends
and wish you to win - to which I say
a fervent Amen

I am sending to you to-day under
separate Cover the documents you sent me

Any other literature you may think will
be helpful to this good cause- Ill be glad to
distribute for you
With best wishes and good hopes
